tn.text: This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
two lesser kings** - "32 lesser kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"kings ruling smaller groups of people"
This is an idiom to express agreement. AT: "I agree with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"tomorrow at the same time of day that it is now"
"Pleasing their eyes" is metonymy for looking at something and desiring it. AT: "whatever pleases them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"The land" is synecdoche for all the people living there. AT: "of the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"Take note" is an idiom to observe carefully. AT: "pay close attention to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This can be expressed positively. AT: "I have agreed to his demands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])

tn.ref: May the gods do so to me and more also
tn.text: This is an oath with great emphasis. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:19:01|19:2]].

tn.ref: if even the ashes of Samaria will be enough for all the people who follow me to have a handful each
tn.text: Ben Hadad is threatening that his army will totally destroy everything in Samaria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Tell Ben Hadad, 'No one who is just putting on his armor ... as if he were taking it off.'
tn.text: This is an expression to give advice. "Putting on armor" is metonymy for getting prepared for battle. "Tell Ben Hadad, 'Do not boast as if you have already won a battle that you have not yet fought.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_proverbs]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "behold" alerts us to the sudden appearance of a new person in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this.

tn.ref: Have you seen this great army?
tn.text: Yahweh asks this question to emphasize the size and strength of Ben Hadad's army. AT: "Look at this great army." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Look, I will place it into your hand today
tn.text: The word "Look" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
Here the word "hand" refers to power. AT: "give you victory over that army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Ahab leaves out the words 'will you do this' AT: "By whom will you do this?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"Ahab assembled the young officers"
"two hundred and thirty-two" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: all the soldiers, all the army of Israel
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"7,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
Here the word "They" refers to the Israelite army.
two lesser kings** - Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:20:01|20:1]].

tn.ref: Ben Hadad was informed by scouts that he had sent out
tn.text: This can be expressed in active form. AT: "Scouts that Ben Hadad had sent out informed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
A "scout" is a soldier sent to gather information about the enemy.
It is understood that Ben Hadad is speaking to his soldiers. AT: "Ben Hadad said to his soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Here "they" and "them" refer to the Israelite army.

tn.ref: So the young officers ... the army followed
tn.text: "The young Israelite officers ... the Israelite army followed"
"Israel" is synecdoche for all the soldiers of the nation of Israel. AT: "the men of the army of Israel pursued them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the king of Israel went out and attacked
tn.text: "The king" is synecdoche for the king and all the soldiers serving under him. AT: "The king of Israel and his soldiers went out and attacked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"Yourself" represents by metonymy the army of the king. AT: "strengthen your forces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These two words mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. AT: "determine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: at the return of the year
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "in the springtime of next year" (UDB) or 2) "at this time next year."

tn.ref: let us fight ... we will be stronger
tn.text: The words "us" and "we" refer to the servants, the king, and the army all together. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: remove all the kings from their positions of authority
tn.text: "You must remove the thirty-two kings who are leading your troops"
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Israel" represents its armed forces by synecdoche. AT: "to fight against the army of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The people of Israel were mustered and supplied
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Israelite army also gathered together, and the commanders gave the arms that they needed for the battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: like two little flocks of goats
tn.text: This simile compares the Israelite army to two little flocks of goats. AT: "The Israelite army appeared to be small and weak like two flocks of goats." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is another title for a prophet. AT: "a prophet" (UDB)

tn.ref: place this great army into your hand
tn.text: Here the word "hand" refers to power. AT: "give you victory over this great army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"7 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"one hundred thousand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A "footman" is a soldier who marches on foot.
The expression "the rest" assumes the words "of the Aramean soldiers." AT: "The rest of the Aramean soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This is the name of a town. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
seven thousand** - "27,000" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This idiom emphasizes what they will say. AT: "Listen" or "Pay attention to what we are about to tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: put sackcloth around our waists and ropes around our heads
tn.text: This was a sign of surrender.
Ahab asks this question to express surprise. AT: "I am surprised that he is still alive!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"My brother" is a metaphor for somebody who is a good friend. AT: "He is like a brother to me" (UDB) or "He is like family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "Now" does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.
"Sign" is metonymy for an action that gives a meaning. AT: "for any action from Ahab that would show them that Ahab wanted to be merciful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: one of the sons of the prophets
tn.text: "a member of the group of prophets"
"the word" is metonymy for the message. AT: "as Yahweh had told him to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have not obeyed the voice of Yahweh
tn.text: "The voice" is metonymy for what Yahweh commanded. AT: "you have not obeyed Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The prophet refers to himself in the third person as a sign of respect to the king.

tn.ref: into the heat of the battle
tn.text: "Heat of the battle" is an idiom to express the most intense and fierce fighting. AT: "to where the battle was most intense" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: then your life will be given for his life
tn.text: "then you will die in his place"
A talent is a unit of weight equal to about 34 kilograms. AT: "34 kilograms of silver" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
This is an idiom to represent being very busy and preoccupied. AT: "doing other things" (UDB) or "doing this and that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "hand" is metonymy for power. AT: "released" or "spared the life of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: your life will take the place of his life, and your people for his people
tn.text: "you will die in his place, and your people will die in the place of his people"
